title: About ViruScan
text:
ViruScan is an application designed to perform contact tracing for respiratory viruses, including COVID-19, flu, RSV, and rhinovirus, at UGA. It is the first app of its kind to do so for multiple respiratory viruses. It utilizes GPS-location tracking and Bluetooth technology to determine participant’s potential contacts. All notifications of exposure are anonymous. Contacts receive information regarding testing. Participants can report cases through the ViruScan module within the UGA Safe App.
ViruScan was created for a course project (EPID 8110 at UGA). Therefore, this website is simply a mock-up demonstrating what a public-facing dashboard for ViruScan would look like. All data utilized to develop graphs and tables were made-up for the purpose of the mock-up.

Watch our Short Video about ViruScan





Frequently Asked Questions



What is ViruScan?


ViruScan is a respiratory virus contact tracing app for students and faculty at the University of Georgia.
Respiratory viruses, such as COVID-19, Influenza, Rhinovirus (the common cold), and Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV), are a great public health concern on college campuses, including the University of Georgia’s.
According to Nichols et al., it has been estimated that roughly 91% of university students contract at least one upper respiratory infection each academic year.
ViruScan’s aim is to reduce transmission of respiratory viral infections by digitizing contact tracing.




How does ViruScan work?


Eligible participants download ViruScan and consent for their location to be tracked via GPS.
Bluetooth technology is used to determine contacts between ViruScan users.
When a user comes into contact with someone who has been diagnosed with a case of a respiratory virus, they will receive a de-identified notification of exposure to a specific illness.
Testing information will be shared alongside the notification.




Who is eligible to download ViruScan?


Faculty, staff, & students of the University of Georgia are eligible to participate in contact tracing via ViruScan.
Students must be 18 years or older and must reside in Athens, GA, or commute to Athens.
In order to participate in contact-tracing, one must enable UGA Safe & ViruScan to track their location.




Is my data private?


Yes, all data collected through ViruScan is private and secure.

Your GPS data is encrypted and stored on a university server.
Your GPS data is deleted 30 days after it is recorded.
Your location will only be tracked in order to determine potential exposures.

Notifications of exposure will always be de-identified in order to protect the privacy of those who are cases, while also informing those who came into contact with cases.
To login to ViruScan, one must use their UGA MyID credentials.




How to download and access ViruScan?



Search ‘UGA Safe’ in your smartphone’s app store.


Download onto your phone and then login using your UGA MyID credentials.


Click on ViruScan within the UGA Safe app and follow in-app set-up instructions. ViruScan will appear on UGA Safe’s homepage.


Enable ViruScan to track your location so it can determine your recent contacts. You can do this in the settings for UGA Safe.

title: Medical Testing for Respiratory Viruses
text:
Medical Testing for Respiratory Viruses



Receiving medical testing for respiratory viruses is crucial to determining whether or not you have contracted a viral illness such as COVID-19, RSV, or the flu.
Testing can help prepare individuals to stay vigilant of complications, in which medical care is required.¹
In terms of contact tracing, testing plays a crucial role as it signals individuals to stay home and isolate in order to reduce transmission.¹


Medical Tests


COVID-19

Nucleic Acid Amplification Tests (NAATs) - gold-standard; administered by healthcare professionals; results in 3 days²
Antigen Tests - at-home tests; results in 15 to 30 minutes²

For negative tests: FDA recommends 2 negative antigen tests for individuals with symptoms 48 hours apart or 3 negative antigen tests for individuals without symptoms 48 hours apart²


Influenza

Molecular Assay – rapid assays provide results in 15-30 minutes; other assays provide results in 45 minutes to an hour³
Antigen Detection Test – rapid tests provide results in 10-15 minutes³

Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)

Nucleic Acid Amplification Tests (NAATs) - highly sensitive; include real-time Reverse Transcription-Polymerase Chain Reaction (rRT-PCR)⁴
Antigen Tests - less sensitive; quicker results⁴

Rhinovirus (Common Cold)

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) tests exist, however, medical providers do not test for rhinovirus typically






Local Medical Testing in Athens, Georgia

title: Vaccines for Respiratory Viruses
text:
Vaccines for Respiratory Viruses



Immunizations help boost the body’s adaptive immune system, which memorizes pathogens that the body has come into contact with. This enables a more rapid response during subsequent exposures.
Vaccines reduce the likelihood of contracting an illness, while also preventing severe illness and death.¹


Vaccinations

COVID-19

You cannot get COVID-19 from the vaccine(s)²
While your body is responding to the vaccine, you may develop a mild fever, headache or chills²
The vaccine(s) do not interact with your DNA²
mRNA Vaccines (Pfizer and Moderna) - introduce lab-made mRNA that simulates production of COVID-19 spike protein to lead to antibody production and memory²
Protein Subunit Vaccine (Novavax) - introduce COVID-19 spike protein²

Influenza

Everyone 6 months or older should get vaccinated³
Under 65 yrs: Inactivated (IIV), Recombinant (RIV), Live Attenuated (LAIV)³
65 yrs and older: Fluzone High-Dose, Flublok Recombinant, Fluad Adjuvanted³
September and October are the best months to get your flu vaccine to prepare for the upcoming flu season³
Shot/Injection - flu virus killed/inactivated; cannot cause flu³
Nasal Spray - flu virus weakened; cannot cause flu³

Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)

RSV Vaccine – everyone over 75 years old (and those of high risk between 50 and 74 years old); Obtain during late summer or early fall⁴
RSV Vaccine/Pfizer’s ABRYSVO – women during 32 - 36 weeks of their pregnancy; Obtain between September and January⁴
RSV Antibodies – babies whose mothers did not receive RSV vaccine while pregnant (and 8-19 month babies at high risk); Obtain beween October and March⁴


Local Vaccination Sites in Athens, Georgia
